intro: Acanthocereus occidentalis, commonly known as the Western Prickly Pear, is a cacti species native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its thick, ribbed stems and clusters of spiny, paddle-shaped pads. The plant produces vibrant yellow or orange flowers during the spring and summer months. Its fruit, a large, spiny berry, is edible when ripe and contains sweet, juicy pulp. This species is well adapted to arid environments and requires minimal water to thrive.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthocereus occidentalis is primarily native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is found in regions such as Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Texas. This cactus thrives in desert and semi-desert environments, often growing on rocky soils. It is commonly associated with areas that have a Mediterranean climate, characterized by hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters. The plant is well adapted to arid conditions and is often seen in rocky canyons and along dry streambeds.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthocereus occidentalis was mainly introduced to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is commonly found in desert environments, particularly in areas with well-drained soils. This cactus is known for its spiny stems and nocturnal blooming flowers.
